Reviews.Content: Good hotel in a good location I booked five nights here through hotels.com for around $110 per night. The Akasaka area is great, plenty of places to eat with very varied cuisines. There are almost as many Italian, Spanish and French places as there are noodle and sashimi restaurants. It's quite a business-oriented area close to the tall Biz Tower, which also means a good supply of coffee shops and convenience stores are close by for breakfast. The hotel also has an Italian restaurant attached, which was reasonably priced for good food.The hotel is quite swish and compact. Decent coffee in the lobby with speedy and friendly check in/out. I had a single room which was so short on floor space I couldn't even leave my suitcase open! Once I'd taken out what I needed all was well though and it's actually a very efficient use of space. Not cramped, not claustrophobic, just little. The door to the bathroom is clear, colourless glass, obviously not an issue in a single room. Internet connection is fast and free, kettle for making tea and an empty fridge for keeping cold things cold. All it really lacked was a place to hang more than two shirts!Other reviews mention the location, being at the top of a short, steep hill or a long flight of stairs. As a result of this, and the hassle in getting to Akasaka metro station from Tokyo railway station with luggage (you need to change lines and it's a lengthy walk up and down stairs between lines and once at Akasaka) I arrived on a humid, hot afternoon wishing I'd just taken a taxi. Unless you only have a small suitcase, or are carrying a backpack, then from Tokyo railway station you're better off going on the metroto Akasaka-Mitsuke, which doesn't require a change of line, and hailing a taxi for the short ride to the hotel, or spending the extra and taking a taxi directly from Tokyo station. Akasaka station is only one one line, but Akasaka-Mitsuke, about 10-15 minutes walk away, is on several and is very useful.
Reviews.Author: gsnichol

Reviews.Content: Ten out of ten - this little hotel ticks all of the boxes I'd never stay anywhere else in Tokyo.The B Akasaka is stylish, affordable, ideally located and has free coffee and net access around the clock. The B Akasaka takes a little hillclimb to reach by foot, but is surprisingly tranquil whilst being in the heart of one of the busiest cities in the world.I'd recommend to take a cab from Akasaka metro station, just to avoid lugging your suitcase up the hill to the hotel.I booked this hotel online and was able to secure a twin bedroom, which was surprisingly spacious for a mere $100 AUD per night. Perfect.
Reviews.Author: TerriandTim

Reviews.Content: Would stay here again! I've just spent a week at the B Akasaka and am very happy with the stay. After reading all the reviews about the tiny hotel rooms and beds in Japan, I was pleasantly surprised. I would definitely recommend the rooms for singles. The bed is amply sized and there is obviously no issue with the lack of privacy in the bathroom. I was particulary pleased with the cleanliness and modern look and feel of the hotel. They also provide a number of extras eg. pjs, slippers, toiletries eg. toothbrush/ toothpaste/ cotton buds/ shampoo/ body wash. The availability of internet in the rooms was a major plus as well (connection was always available and speedy).I had no issue with the location either but can see that travellers with a lack of fitness may struggle (or need to get a taxi), as the hotel is off the main road and up a number of stairs or up an incline.

Reviews.Content: not bad I'm here right now. It's nice, clean, relatively central, just about big enough (in my single room)  most importantly cheap.If you're thinking of booking here, I'd advise you to at least look into Shibuya Granbell, a hotel of similar cost and proportions (seemingly not listed on tripadvisor), only a bit trendier and slap bang in Shibuya. I think it would be a bit better for the party-going 20-somethings like myself, but the B would surely be better for those a bit older or after a more relaxed time.I read some reviews stating it was hard to get to the b from the stations. Not so at all. There is one super-quick unofficial route (presumably not listed as you have to cut through a nursery.Exit at Akasaka gate 7, take a right until you see some 'n' shaped metallic barriers, go up the flight of stairs past the weird cat-umbrella village, you'll see the b.I'd say to improve, some form or wardrobe storage would be v.useful as I have had to open and close my case every time i have wanted anything, otherwise there is no space to stand. Under-bed storage would be a benefit too  the breakfasts could be a couple-hundred yen cheaper, or free as standard, other than that - can't complain.
Reviews.Author: pdoherty

Reviews.Content: Recommended Pretty good place. The rooms were bigger than I was expecting given all the hype about tiny rooms in Tokyo. The bathroom was large enough, but it was built fishtank style with frosted glass up to about eye height, meaning you can see in from the room. It doesn't pay to be shy.As far as location goes it was pretty good. There are hundreds of restaurants just around the corner and the Akasaka Metro station is only a couple of 100 metres away, except that line isn't all that useful so to get anywhere you generally have to make two or three changes. I did two trips to Narita airport and averaged two hours per trip (using the Narita Express from Tokyo station).The staff are friendly, just watch out for the PC in the lobby, the keyboard kept changing back and forth from English to Japanese script, quite confusing until I figured out what I was doing wrong!
Reviews.Author: Regsun

Reviews.Content: Good value in central Tokyo After staying with friends in Tokyo we had to spend one nght in a hotel. We wanted somewhere nice, central and inexpensive. Having read the reviews we opted for B Akasaka. It fitted the bill perfectly. Akasaka, primarily a nightlife area, is in the heart of Tokyo. The hotel, in a quiet office cum residential part of Akasaka, is only 5 minutes walk from a subway station, restaurants and bars. It is a renovated business hotel which now looks boutique like. Ambient lighting in the lobby etc. The rooms are small but comfortable and a bit chic. The compact bathroom was quite cool. We didn't need a wardrobe or drawers, which is just as well as there weren't any! This really is a place for a short stay. Service at check-in was typically friendly. At Yen 20,000 for a double room this was good value for the centre of Tokyo. A bit of advice: as the hotel is at the top of short but steep hill don't arrive by subway if you have baggage. But we walked down to the station when we left - it takes under half an hour from the hotel via the subway to Tokyo City Air Terminal, from where you can catch a coach to Narita airport.

Reviews.Content: Very nice, modern, small hotel. A friend and I stayed at the B Akasaka for two evenings. This was a great value for the amount we paid ($150 per night for two twins). We were very impressed by how modern the hotel was and all the amenities (refrigerator, flat screen, nice lighting, robes, slippers, awesome coffee, computer in lobby). The rooms were quite small but were fine for our needs. Bathroom is very modern with many nice features but is separated from room by frosted glass which took a while to get used to. We really enjoyed the neighborhood around the hotel. It is walking distance to lots of bars and restaurants. We enjoyed being in a quieter part of town but having lots of options of things to do. There is a restaurant in the hotel but we never ate there. We found it easy to take the subway to other parts of Tokyo (Shinjuku, Asakasa). On the way in we took the subway to a central location (Ropongi) and then got a cab to bring us to the hotel. This was a good plan and was only 1200 yen or so. Hotel was very helpful in providing advice on getting to the domestic airport (Haneda). Highly recommend this hotel.
Reviews.Author: plainjane72

Reviews.Content: Compact stylish hotel! The rooms are tiny! Having travelled and stayed in hotels around the world, this was the smallest I'd ever seen! Not particularly a bad thing though, the room was extremely clean and very stylish. There was enough space to put 2 medium-large suitcases (after a bit of rearranging!). The lobby is awesome, just like the website photos. There is a complimentary coffee machine (cafe style) and also a coin operated laundry with vending machines. Internet access is not great. There is one communal laptop in the lobby that has a constant line of people waiting patiently to check email etc. Otherwise, you can pay for in-room internet access. The hotel is located close to the train station but not easy to find, particularly with suitcases in hand! Be warned, there are over 30 steps between the train station and the hotel to take (uphill). Great little boutique hotel, recommended for those who don't mind small spaces!
Reviews.Author: nyrak

Reviews.Content: badly located and overrated I have tested 5 hotels in Tokyo over the past 2 years and this one in my worst experience.First of all you must know that 90% of the taxi drivers do not know where the hotel is located since the name has changed mid 2007 and most drivers know it with its previous name. If you decide to use the subway, I would advise you travel light because the hotel is on the top of a hill and you will have to carry you case(s) all the way up with unfriendly stairs or on unpractical sidewalks.When it comes to the hotels it self, the rooms are clean but very small and you do not want to share the rooms with somebody you work with if you are not intimate... All bathrooms are separated from the bedrooms by a transparent glasswall. It's nice but not necessarily appropriate.Beds are small, working table is nanoscopic.Breakfast is ok. And pay attention to the fact that you will heavily be charged extra fees if you plan to stay after the forecast checkout.In brief, hotel to be avoided !Pierre
Reviews.Author: Kardvader

Reviews.Content: Very modern, outstanding service, good location. I would highly recommend this hotel. It is well located between Roppongi, Shibuya and Ginza and is very well designed as well as beautifully kept. The rooms are small but this is no capsule hotel. If you are looking for a base to explore from then this is great but dont' choose it if you are looking to spend lots of time at the hotel. The highlight for us was definitely the outstanding service. The reception staff could genuinly not do enough for us e.g. running into the street at 5am to catch a cab for us and tell the driver in Japanese where we wanted to go to.Highly recommend.
